utterances: Having been ahead of the curve both as a punk in the '70s and a new wave popster in the '80s, Weller today is all about looking back to the sound of the '60s, the mod bands, like The Small Faces and The Kinks.
Definitely, yeah.
I mean, that was kind of like my sort of formative years for me musically--from like '66 onwards for me.
That's when I kind of really got into music as a kid, and I feel like first impressions always stay with you.
That will always be the kind of foundation of what I do, I think.
(Soundbite of music)
(Singing) What's in a life if you don't live it, baby?
Just a gettin' by with the promise: What if?
Maybe?
On his latest solo release, ""As Is Now,"" Weller, true to form, runs very competently through a gamut of styles from blues rock to dance pop to hippie folk.
There are nice touches in the playing and arranging throughout.
But I sometimes find it hard to figure out why he's writing what he does; that musically and lyrically the songs can lack a coherent personality or a central voice.
It's just, `Here's a love ballad.
How about a dance pop tune?
Now a '60s hippie folk song.'
(Soundbite of music)
(Singing) I know it takes to start up a river.
That's a long time.
One tune on this album that does seem to come from a more definite place is a song called ""Savages.
(Soundbite of ""Savages"")
(Singing) Savages--he knows you are.
Do you not think that God is looking down on savages?
Children run to mothers.
You put bullets in their backs.

What it's specifically written about basically--just that image for me of when the army went into the school, and the kids tried to escape and running out into the playground to their parents and being shot in the back by so-called freedom fighters.
You know, I just thought--I don't know how much lower that mankind can sink to, really.
Weller's still a huge star in Britain, but through all these years he's been unable to grow beyond a devoted core following here in the US.
In fact, he told me he didn't know if he could continue coming to the States to tour at all.
He says he loses money every time he makes the trip.
Fortunes, man.
Fortune.
How come?
Because we've still got the same costs, you know: the trucks, your lights, you got wages, hotels, flights, da-da-dum.
You know, it's never-ending.
Those costs are all the same, but we're not making the same money back, you know.
So often our UK tours finance everywhere else we play in the world.
Well, despite some of my quibbles with the latest album, don't give up on us yet, Mr. Weller.
We hope to see you back here stateside a few more times.
(Soundbite of song)
(Singing) Black French chicken on an empty dime.
I only want what I know is mine.
Sound the bells 'cause here's the good news.
Christian Bordal reviews music for DAY TO DAY.
(Soundbite of song)
(Singing) Comments coming, going to wait no more.
Can I get a piece for me?
More coming up on DAY TO DAY from NPR News.
This is DAY TO DAY.
I'm Alex Chadwick.
The Senate Judiciary Committee has concluded its public questioning of Judge John Roberts.
The nominee for chief justice of the United States spent more than 20 hours this week answering--or frequently declining to answer--questions from committee members.
The full Senate could vote on Judge Roberts' nomination by the end of the month.
NPR's Ari Shapiro reports.
This morning marked the Democrats' last attempt to get a clear picture of the man who may soon become the head of not only the Supreme Court but of the whole federal judiciary.
From the outset, ranking Democrat Patrick Leahy of Vermont made clear his dissatisfaction with the process thus far.
(Soundbite of hearing)
Judge, you're really going to miss us, aren't you?
I mean, you're going to miss doing this every day.
I mean, it's--you're not going to even answer that one, are you?
Well, it's...
Roberts did answer some questions about judicial ethics, the death penalty and courts that can authorize secret wiretaps.

But he also repeated responses that have become familiar over the last few days, such as, `It depends on the facts of the case,' and `Those were the views of my client at the time, not my personal views.
Those kinds of answers have frustrated Democrats like California Senator Dianne Feinstein, who said she still doesn't know how she'll vote on the nominee.
(Soundbite of hearing)
It doesn't sound like progress is very good right now in that respect.
Yeah.
Let's go John(ph) in Bethesda, Maryland.
Hi, John.

I had one impression of you when we had our hour in private and to a great extent I think I came out of that meeting with a different sense of you, and of course the impression that I have today is of this very cautious, very precise man.
Almost all of the committee Democrats took advantage of an optional third round of questioning.
New York Senator Charles Schumer said after two rounds he still doesn't know who Roberts is.
(Soundbite of hearing)

Well, if you were sitting here, what question would you ask John Roberts so that we could be--so that you, or us, could be sure that we weren't nominating what I call an ideologue, someone who you might define as somebody who wants to make law, not interpret law?
And then how would you answer the question you asked yourself?
(Soundbite of laughter)
I'd begin by saying, `Well, that's a good question, sir.'
Roberts said he'd ask many of the questions that have already been put to him.
(Soundbite of hearing)
I've talked about how I would approach cases involving the right to privacy under the liberty clause.
I've talked about how I would approach cases involving government enforcement in the antitrust case.
How about something that you haven't talked--a question that hasn't been asked?
Well...
Since some of us are still unsure.
Roberts replied that some nominees might discuss their personal views, but he doesn't allow his personal views to influence his judgments, so he's chosen not to discuss them in this hearing.
He has over the last few days given Congress some advice on how they can get the results they want from the federal judiciary.
Yesterday he told committee members that they could write new laws to handle a controversial property rights case decided by the Supreme Court last term.
And today, he again advised the legislative branch.
In response to Senator Leahy's complaint about judges who rule against plaintiffs seeking to bring anti-discrimination lawsuits in federal court, Roberts said this.
(Soundbite of hearing)
If Congress wants them to sue, all Congress has to do is write one sentence saying individuals harmed by a violation of this statute may bring a right of action in federal court.
There are laws where Congress says that, and that question never comes up.
This afternoon, Roberts gets a break while witnesses testify for and against him.
Ari Shapiro, NPR News, Washington.
This is TALK OF THE NATION.
I'm Neal Conan, in Washington.
In Woody Allen's 1973 film ""Sleeper,"" Allen's character wakes up from a deep freeze 200 years in the future.
The world is run by a Big Brother-type authoritarian government where robots do much of the domestic work.
Allen disguises himself as a servant robot with a silver painted face and a dome on his head and gets fitted for a suit by two robotic, yet very Jewish tailors.
It's a satiric take on the play that gave robots their name: Karel Capek's ""R.U.R.,"" which stands for Rossum's Universal Robots.
You might be more familiar with ""The Terminator.
